text: the frantic search for survivors goes on
round-the-clock
following Nepal's biggest earthquake in
80 years
the injured were brought to hospitals in
trucks and on rickshaws the hospitals
are so inundated though they're running
out of space amateur video captured the
moment the earthquake struck and the
ensuing panic hi the ground shook quite
hard for I would say possibly about 30
seconds looking around I happened to be
outdoors at the time trees were waving
like crazy like it was a hurricane or
something like that the capital
Kathmandu is an ancient city with a rich
cultural heritage much of it now in
ruins the 19th century Dodaro tower
built by Nepalese royalty and this is
what's left a world heritage site where
teams now look for bodies as reports
come in from remote areas in the
mountains which actually haven't been
reached yet so I think the number one
priority at the moment is logistics to
actually reach the areas of the
epicentre and the the valleys that have
that are very remote and the highways
have been blocked by landslides so
there's no way to get there so first an
assessment and rescue in another rescue
operation the first helicopter arrived
at Mount Everest base camp where
climbers and guides were killed after
the quake triggered an avalanche as
rescuers raced to find survivors a major
international aid effort has been
prepared Britain the United States and
Pakistan among the countries sending in
teams to help with the number of dead
rising it's clear that help is needed
fast
Nick Qureshi BBC news
